title: Wednesday, 18th July, 2018

In response, the chairman says "screw you, shareholders."

BE11:12am

I paraphrase. But only a little.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

"The Group has made further progress in the first quarter and I am pleased with the trading performance of the core businesses over the same period. RPC remains well placed to work with customers at the design stage and throughout the product lifecycle to drive a sustainable future for plastic. The Board strongly believes in the strengths and prospects of the Group.

However, pressure on the company's market valuation and differing investor views on the appropriate level of leverage is constraining the Group's ability to pursue some attractive opportunities for growth and your Board is working to resolve this. In the short-term, the Group will prioritise cash generation and the announced disposal of our non-core businesses, with a view to generating increased capital for deployment in the business or further returns to shareholders."

BE11:12am

Okay, so what does that mean?

Excel Developer I think these sessions should be permanently 30 minutes if Bryce is permanently expected to do them solo.
Fox I note Vodafone is trading at levels not seen since 2010. Dividend yield up around 7.5% and expected to be maintained through FCF.

We'll try to set minds at ease about the slew of acquisitions and disconnect between earnings and cashflow?

11:16 am
BE11:16am

While we believe there may be some disappointment that RPC did not announce another £100m buyback (2%-3% EPS accretive), we interpret the chairman's comments to mean that RPC is looking to increase its available capital for attractive bolt-on M&A opportunities. However, in the absence of capital deployment opportunities in the business, capital will be returned to shareholders (in our view, likely via larger future share buybacks rather than dividends).

VV75 no, please enlighten me excel
cheeckychappy floated at 230p!
VV75 or cheeky rather
BE11:16am

Re-rating opportunity medium term: While RPC's roadmap to re-rating won't happen overnight, delivery of the following should see the valuation discount to peers narrow over the next 12-18 months: 1) org sales growth of 2%-3% or “ahead of respective GDP"; 2) underlying EBIT growth & demonstrating contract provisions can be realized; 3) improved cash conversion & comfort that growth capex is supporting high return org growth; 4) synergy delivery from prior M&A (€105m by Mar-19); 5) over-delivery of "at least" £50m EBIT growth target by FY21; and 6) improved market communication increasing investor confidence in estimates.

BE11:17am

And Caz.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Organic growth in Q1 19 was 2.0%. This is below the long-term trend (c3%) and the rate for FY18 (2.8%). The Q1 19 performance was achieved against comparatively strong organic growth in Q1 18 and is not, in our opinion, indicative of a slowdown in demand. We believe there is no reason to expect full-year organic growth to deviate from prior expectations. Beyond that, we think there was little to get excited about in this morning’s statement. Apart, perhaps, from an intriguing final paragraph that stated the Board was ‘working to resolve’ the constraints placed upon its ability to pursue opportunities for growth from ‘pressure on the company’s market valuation and differing investor views on the appropriate level of leverage’. This is all very interesting and we look forward to seeing how the Board approaches the resolution of these issues.

undefined

ASML? Cripes, yeah, okay.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

ASML’s results and outlook point at continuing solid market conditions and continued strong execution. We believe the earnings power and growth implied by ASML’s 2020 objectives have been the prime focus of investors in the recent past. With ASML having received orders in Q1 from three clients for four R&D high-NA EUV tools to be shipped towards the end of 2021 and ASML having sold options for eight volume-production high-NA EUV tools (with shipment due in 2024), the focus is set to shift beyond 2020, with new long-term targets likely to be provided at the CMD on 8 November. Our TP is based on 16x 2020E earnings potential of EUR10 per share, although we see significant further potential beyond 2020E.

BE11:24am

there is a rather odd complaint from the Chairman about the company’s valuation and assessment of leverage from some shareholders, hampering the company’s ability to undertake attractive opportunities for growth, i.e. make acquisitions. It is unusual for a Chairman to grumble about this, but we welcome the lack of big M&A. We would argue that this is the only way that shareholders will truly be able to judge the underlying profit growth.

BE11:24am

We think the underlying FCF growth was -20% to -30% YoY in FY18 and the EBIT growth inflated through provision accounting. In short, we think RPC has been stripping out losses that are embedded in acquisitions in the P&L post consolidation mostly through provisions (cash losses, not P&L) and claiming this as growth, when it is just accounting. We have been writing, for some time about this, and still view it as misleading. With few acquisitions on the horizon, it will be easier to see if we are right, starting with 1H results in November. We expect a negative FCF trend to be clear and obvious then. We remain sellers, seeing fair value at 10x our FY19 FCF estimate, or 430p.

Blank canvas Unilever (of which I hold many) making some sort of a comeback?
cheeckychappy Foxtons, Countrywide etc...
Upaswellasdown that property report shows large falls in volumes in 2017 and 2018 - down by 19% and 5% respectively yoy. Indicates prices will fall further as sellers who need to move start to lower asking prices

On estate agents, I guess we can hoof out the JPM buy note that came out yesterday, since there seems to be demand.

Blank canvas Tick tock. Time to go. Thanks BE. see you tomorrow
BE11:28am

Post Purplebricks’ FY18 results presentation, we keep our bullish view on
the business long term despite short term headwinds. Yes, FY19 guidance
(revenues of £165-185m) was disappointing – but largely a reflection of weak
macro (both UK/Australia) rather than the indication of structural issues we
believe. The company’s KPIs remain impressive on all fronts and despite
meaningful cuts to short term estimates (arguably small changes on absolute
numbers but larger % changes) we factor in a +60% revenues CAGR 2018A -
2022E. We believe positive comments around the U.S. rollout (the company
also just launched in Phoenix and Arizona after New York earlier this year)
will provide a positive catalyst, outweighing a continuously difficult UK
market post the Brexit vote. Our target price of 500p (previously 596p)
provides +60% potential upside.

BE11:29am

They're believers.

11:28 am
BE11:29am

Given their low and flexible cost base compared to traditional agents, the
company prices competitively – we estimate the average fee is about 70%
lower. In addition, its propriety technology puts the entire process of buying
and selling properties Online, keeping time spent to a minimum for all
parties involved (80% of traffic at times when agency offices are closed).
Given this dynamic, the model is gaining traction – Purplebricks is already
the largest agent overall in the UK and we believe market share will
increase further from c.6% today to at least 15% by 2022E (if not more).
Given the strong momentum, we are even more positive on the U.S.
opportunity than before and Canada has proven successful already (20%
market share in Quebec is an impressive example).
